content.text: The editor state of today
When we first started, the Fabric Editor has always
positioned itself to be the
most effective way to communicate
ideas with your team. We started humbly from an architectural rewrite to support
Bitbucket, Jira, Stride and now Confluence
, embarking on a journey to ship a common collaboration experience cross product. Today, with over
1.8 million deduped MAU
(> 2m minus duplicate) and
25 million monthly edit sessions
, the editor surpasses even Confluence (1.6m) and Bitbucket(1.5m) as the
4th most used experience
after Trello, Jira Software, and Jira Platform. This is huge. People do rely on us a lot for content creation and collaboration.
Where do we go from now?
Compared to the old experience, we scored relatively equal in the customer satisfaction score. Today, we have officially surpassed TinyMCE, clocking a score of
~4/5 CSAT
without even all the extra functionality that the old editor provides. This is a significant milestone.

But what makes the difference between a 4 and a perfect 5? This is where delighters and an awesome user experience comes in. We want less of ‚ÄúWhy are images not loading?‚Äù and more of ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt know I could do that, that‚Äôs awesome!‚Äù. And we think that the editor is only in the beginning of the journey to make this happen.
Leveraging on existing research

At the end of every vision piece presentation, someone will inevitably put on the pragmatic hat and say: ‚ÄúSo what‚Äôs the problem you‚Äôre trying to solve?‚Äù. That‚Äôs fair, considering we sometimes build cool features during Shipit or innovation week ‚Äújust because‚Äù. This is why we need to understand the customer problems that our vision is going to solve. The immediate gut reaction is ‚Äúresearch‚Äù. But instead of embarking on an epic quest to unify the
string
teamwork theory, there‚Äôs already plenty of existing literature that we can synthesise upon. From
team personas
, nagareboshi,
unit of work
Cambrian Saas
, outcome driven development,
polaris
, and now
top tasks

, the list is countless. What we know is, there‚Äôs always an appetite to understand the universally common work journeys, across different facets of a team. So what do teams do in the context of work?
6 things all teams do
From all the existing research, we created an
affinity map
to categorise and group information so that we can understand to top jobs to be done for all teams. We found that
all teams
1. Plan and coordinate projects.
This is by far the number one task across all teams. Roadmapping, setting goals and delivering on project outcomes is common from Software to Marketing and HR team.
2. Go to meetings
Meetings is the most common way to communicate, sync up and coordinate between work and who‚Äôs doing that work. This can range from a one on one to a formal presentation.
3. Track and report work
High performing team track their work in one readily accessible place. This is then reviewed within a cadence to understand and improve on what‚Äôs working and what‚Äôs not working.
4. Engage in team cohesiveness

Every team needs to work towards a common goal. On the way to get there, there is a need for every individual contributor to provide ideas, resolve issues, and acknowledging the efforts and outputs of team members.
5. Need productive individuals

Focus work of individual contributors is crucial to how performant a team is. Individuals within a team is also often times found engaging independent and creative thoughts to the more ‚Äúadmin‚Äù like activities like sorting out personal plan or transferring knowledge to a colleague.
6. Need to do some maintenance work
Maintenance work spans the more invisible work around making sure information is organised and accessible to everyone who needs to know a particular aspect work.
Where does the editor fit in?
We believe that when it comes to the editor, we help teams perform by excelling at the three fundamental themes: helping teams connect, capture work, and express themselves.
The editor helps users to express their thoughts and ideas in various mediums across our products. Any content can be expressed in different views, fit for a wide variety of context.
E.g. from post-its to roadmap, from table to issues, a page to slides.
The editor is the place to capture all types of work. This can then be referenced and created through a familiar experience regardless of products and space.
E.g. actions, decisions, create Jira issue from everywhere, search and pick links in 3rd party provider.
The editor connects different teams together and make it possible to collaborate in a single place to move work forward, regardless of tools or boundaries.
E.g. collab editing across languages, mentions, inline comments
Show me the money
1) So long static content, hello dynamic data

The story begins with the founders of a company detailing the new, refreshed plan for the year forward. After months of working hard and finalising on the company objective and key results, the leadership team is finally ready to summarise it all in a
one pager
. The dream is to make this 100% transparent to teams and employees, making sure that everyone can openly see the accurate reflection of the past and the future.

Communicating this game plan in the right way is important to set the tone for how teams work. This process typically takes months to prepare. You‚Äôd need to scramble to get an update from all teams, pull the right metrics, and finally put everything together into a Confluence page and then a Keynote presentation. That‚Äôs a lot of hard work. What if the editor can help streamline this process?
What if the founders can track the most up-to-date objectives through one single table, which can then transform seamlessly for a presentation?
Here‚Äôs how CEOs can present their source of truth in
Confluence
, powered by the Fabric Editor:
Tableution + Jira (or any other apps, really)

Jira is great for bringing together a centralised place to track items but hard to use. Tables are familiar and easy to manipulate but lacks power. Combining the two compliments each other by making the one source of truth easier to learn and use.
Presentation mode
What if pages / nodes can be shareable and presentable? This will reduce the amount of back and forth between Confluence page and Keynote while keeping the source of truth within our ecosystem.
2) Consistent experience and deep integration across our suite

After the founders presentation, it‚Äôs clear that we should be putting more emphasis on the less performant objectives. The first plan is to really understand the problems by talking to customers. Thankfully we have a research centre where people can sign up for interviews. Powered by Jira Service Desk, users can signup for a customer research session or submit feedback of their experience.

This is where the benefit of a cross product editor comes in. With a consistent content creation experience, users can express their feedback using common elements like uploading media or link without the product teams having to do a single work.
Here‚Äôs how a customer might be submitting feedback through
Jira Service Desk
, powered by the Fabric Editor:

Awesome. So this then gets submitted as a ticket and stored in Jira. Now, what typically happens is feedback often goes to the black hole because it lives in separate projects and tracked in different tools. Ideally, we‚Äôd want to bring this closer together. What if within a single project, you‚Äôre free to create pages as you‚Äôd like, using all the editor goodness and awesome tables? That way you can record customer interview sessions in the same place where the work happen.

What‚Äôs even more awesome is the Fabric Editor of the future is tightly integrated with other 3rd party tools. Imagine a case where you are trying to organise interviews. You‚Äôd have to manage events in Calendly or Google Calendar and go back and forth with tracking it in Atlassian tools. What if you can automatically pull the event date with a table column powered by Google Calendar itself? This streamlines the whole shenanigans around scheduling calendar tetris in one simple table. Furthermore, since each row can be made into a Jira object, this gets autopopulated straightaway as a custom field within issue view. Allowing a more seamless communication between agent and customer.
Here‚Äôs how a researcher might be managing interviews within
Jira Software
, powered by the Fabric Editor:
Page as a service

We‚Äôve been thinking of the editor only living in certain places within Jira (description and commen). What if it can also live as a view? Being able to create report as a writeup and then present it using the editor.
Columns, powered by apps
Google Calendar is only one use case. There are a multitude of other use cases where you can set a column for Slack to send precanned responses, etc.
3) Ideation and synthesis across all mediums

Now that we‚Äôve done the research, it‚Äôs time to collate the result and come up with ideas to solve the problems. This ideation session typically happens in a meeting or a workshop, involving multiple stakeholders covered in reams of post it notes. But what happens next? Someone will inevitably have to writeup all the findings and synthesize the results into a document.

This is where the magic happens. In the future people would be able to take photos of the results and automatically detect post it notes and whiteboard sketches. This is the perfect companion use case for a mobile editor, digital post it notes can be created automatically on the go, reducing the amount of time doing repetitive work.
Here‚Äôs how a team lead might be capturing work artefacts on
Confluence Mobile
, powered by the Fabric Editor.
AI powered content detection

Being able to transcribe post it notes is only one use case of AI in content collaboration. What if we could also autocomplete content while typing? or being able to generate content with voice & speech?
Editor apps across medium.

The editor is optimised for long form written communication. But a lot of team activities require a more free form visual communication like being able to create diagram, murals, and post it notes. How can we support all types of mediums and accessibility needs?
4. Seamless transformation of content

Great, so now we‚Äôve generated a bunch of ideas and improvements through our smart mobile editor companion. How do we quickly turn these ideas into a roadmap? What if you can just select a couple of those upvoted post it notes and then turn them into a table. What‚Äôs more, since we support different types of data visualisations in the table - a roadmap view can be generated with a single click. Each item can then be converted into a Jira epic and tracked over time.
Here‚Äôs how a product manager can go from ideas to roadmap by leveraging the
combined power of Jira and Confluence
, powered by the Fabric Editor.
Table visualization
Because tables can be treated as a database, it unlocks the potential to be visualised in interesting ways. This can be in the form of cards, charts, or in this case a roadmap.
Cross flow with the editor

Our products are awesome at doing its main jobs to be done. However, the editor can unlock more cross flow between products by surfacing meaningful entry points that helps enhance the purpose of each of our tools.
Open up each epic and then set a success measure.
The future of done
5) Lightning fast way to reuse content

Awesome. So now that the roadmap is decided, time to actually design the solution. Often time people find that they are creating the same page structure all over again. Be it a design spec, a DACI, or documentation piece, there is an opportunity to save time by allowing users to predefine reusable bits. These snippets can then be shared across different teams to ensure consistency and maintain a standard within the company. What would be even more awesome is if we can autosuggest templates by detecting the page title alone.
Here‚Äôs how a designer can increase productivity by leveraging the power of
Confluence
templates, powered by the Fabric Editor.

Say that the design documentation is done. Let‚Äôs skip forward to actual developer implementing the feature. A pull request is submitted in Bitbucket and pending approval from the designer. Using the same editor, the designer can then comment and link an updated version of the prototype. What‚Äôs awesome is she can actually access Invision and third party tools from within the comment without having to switch context. The developer can then rely on inspect tools from Invision to make sure the end result is pixel perfect.
Here‚Äôs how a developer can collaborate and review work with precision in
Bitbucket
, powered by the Fabric Editor.
Snippets

Snippets allow users to define editor elements in a meaningful way that can be shared to other team members. With snippets, users can create pre-canned responses to post-mortem templates, allowing for faster content creation and increased productivity. Targeted at the maker-type users, they are also a vehicle to spread best practices within an organisation.
Smart links

Smart links enables user to share documents, links, and content from all across the web and express them in inline, block, or interactive embed. This is the key to reducing context switching and keeping users engaged within our suite of products.
Communicate under any situation

Emergencies can happen at any time when teams least expect it. At this crucial point, teams need to be able to swiftly react to incidents and create incidents under pressure. This is where mobile shines. Using the lightweight version of the mobile editor, people can immediately describe the details of the incident with speed and precision.
Here‚Äôs how an on-call developer can immediately report an incident on
Opsgenie
, powered by the Fabric Editor.

While resolving an incident, responders will also often create a postmortem that details all the executive summary, leadup, and root causes so that future handling of the incident can be improved. Often times, this requires the responder to also create Jira tickets to further investigate the technical aspects that needs fixing. What if it‚Äôs easy to just create a ticket within Opsgenie, or better yet, across all of our products? Here‚Äôs an example of how it works:
7) Collaborate across boundaries

Once the emergency is resolved, the team members can then take next steps and actions in a meeting. This might happen across different continents, across multiple languages. What would be awesome is the ability to automatically transcribe your voice input, and then live translate the content based on user preferences. Here‚Äôs how an on-call developer can immediately report an incident on
Confluence
, powered by the Fabric Editor.
8) Track results and celebrate wins
At last, we‚Äôve gone through the full circle of work trying to improve the customer experience, complete with firefighting
aw snaps

incidents. We should be seeing some impact on the goals we‚Äôve set at the beginning of the year. Going back to the same page again, it‚Äôs easy to just hover through our key metrics and find out more details by seeing a rich preview of the links. Success of failure, there should be an easy way to send updates and celebrate the wins and learnings to the team across different channels out there.
Here‚Äôs how CEOs can give encouragement to the hardworking teams on
Confluence
, powered by the Fabric Editor.
